Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Using Tree Rings to Develop Critical Scientific and Mathematical Thinking Skills in Undergraduate Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is a collaborative effort among Columbia University, U.S. Military Academy at West Point, Passaic County Community College, and Centralia College to develop, evaluate and refine undergraduate science and mathematical modules based on applications of tree rings to age dating, climate and environmental change, volcanic hazards, statistical modeling, and forensic science. Interactive multi-media modules are being made available through a website and are accompanied by background material and guidelines for flexible use to instructor adoption. Students can measure tree-ring widths virtually and/or use datasets to conduct inquiry-based investigations and quantitative analyses, with an emphasis on learning the process of science. The project is also conducting faculty-development workshops at the partnering institutions, and undertaking rigorous evaluation of learning outcomes.

The intellectual merit of the project lies in its innovative approach to leveraging the readily grasped basic premise and wide range of applicability of tree-ring science to engage students in learning scientific methods and quantitative reasoning. Broader impacts include infusion of tree-ring science in the undergraduate curriculum at the diverse partnering institutions and beyond. Skills and attitudes imparted by the modules both benefit students who go on in STEM and bolster scientific literacy among the general population.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our curriculum project has been a collaborative effort among Columbia University, U.S. Military Academy at West Point, Passaic County Community College, and Centralia College. We set out to develop, evaluate, and refine undergraduate science and mathematical modules for labs and classes based on applications of tree rings to age dating, climate and environmental change, volcanic hazards, statistical modeling, and forensic science.

Serious studies of tree rings (dendrochronology) began in the early 1900s when astronomer Andrew Douglass was seeking a way to measure the effect of the sun on climate in the American Southwest. Douglass found recognizable patterns in tree-ring growth that he could relate to climate phenomena, such as the amount of precipitation in an area, and that could be recognized over broad areas. By 1929 he was able to use a regional chronology of tree rings that he had developed from old trees to date timbers from archaeological sites that had been inhabited by the ancient Puebloan peoples of the American Southwest during the 13th century and extending back more than five centuries—His work pre-dated the development of radiocarbon dating in 1947 and revolutionized the study of prehistory, for the first time allowing dating of past events to the year. This breakthrough and subsequent development of tree-ring laboratories, analysis and measurement equipment and techniques, and statistical methods for evaluating tree ring measurements has made tree-ring science invaluable for studying not only past climate, environmental, and geologic history, but also for evaluating and dating modern landscape processes such landslide movement as well as for aiding in the radiocarbon dating of ancient “subfossil” trees or wood structures.

We have incorporated interactive multi-media modules via an outside website and have provided  background material on the history and importance of the topics in the modules. We have also prepared guidelines to allow instructors flexibility in the adoption of the modules. Students can measure tree-ring widths virtually and/or use datasets to conduct inquiry-based investigations and quantitative analyses, with an emphasis on learning the process of science. We have given presentations on the modules at various science and professional society meetings and will continue to do this to broadcast the utility of the modules. We will also conduct faculty-development workshops at partnering institutions and continue to undertake rigorous evaluation of learning outcomes.

The intellectual merit of the project lies in its innovative approach to leveraging the readily grasped basic premise and wide range of applicability of tree-ring science to engage students in learning scientific methods and quantitative reasoning.  The modules satisfy outcomes such as symbolic, temporal, analytical, and abstract reasoning skills as well—All integral to STEM-related classes. Broader impacts include infusion of tree-ring science in the undergraduate curriculum at the diverse partnering institutions and beyond. Skills and attitudes imparted by the modules both benefit students who go on in STEM and bolster scientific literacy among the general population.

One example of a module noted above is Lab 2 - Tree Rings and Pueblo Bonito: Uncovering the Past. In this lab students learn about the ancient Puebloan culture and analyze a scan of a historic timber from Pueblo Bonito ruin at Chaco Canyon using a traditional method of analysis invented by Douglass, skeleton plotting, on a segment of the sample. They then try to match their skeleton plot with one done on the sample by a scientist from the Laboratory of Tree-Ring Research in 1971. Students then measure the rings of the same segment, plot their measurements using Excel other spreadsheet software, and then match the time series plot they have created with a skeleton plot. In one exercise they normalized or detrend their measurements using Excel in order to remove the biological growth curve and create dimensionless indices that can be compared more easily with data from other tree-ring chronologies such as an extensive one from El Malpais National Monument, not far from Chaco Canyon. Students who completed these lab exercises gained insights into the historical aspects of the ancient Puebloans, learned about the materials they used for their buildings, gained experience using tree-ring techniques to measure wood samples, and also analyzed the data they created to crossdate or match samples.
